text: Department of the Treasury Internal Revenue Service
This transmits revised IRM 9.7.13, Title 26 Seizures for Forfeiture
9.7.13.4.4.(2) is revised to reflect that the use of forfeitures in tax and tax-related may require approval by the Department Of Justice, Tax Division.
Position titles have been updated throughout the section to reflect the new organizational titles were effective with the October 1, 2011, reorganization of Criminal Investigation.
Additional revisions, deletions, and grammatical changes were made throughout the section, that did not result in substantive changes but contributed to procedural clarity of the subject matter.

for Forfeiture
page (
) There are only two methods of forfeiture under the Internal Revenue Code (Title
), administrative and civil judicial. These methods are commonly referred to as “code forfeitures” or “Title

forfeitures.” There is no provision for criminal forfeiture. Only property used, or intended to be used, to violate Internal Revenue laws can be forfeited. Proceeds of such a violation is not feitable. In addition, there are no “tracing” provisions with code forfeitures. Accordingly, the property purchased with proceeds is also not forfeitable. (
) This section deals only with Title
forfeitures. Because these forfeitures involve violations of the Internal Revenue laws, the guidelines and require- ments that have to be followed differ in many ways from those involving Title

forfeitures. This section provides information on the authority of the agents to seize, the type of property authorized, methods that can be used when making a seizure, and the pre-seizure issues that must be considered. also explains the steps necessary to process a forfeiture, the types of that can be filed by claimants prior to forfeiture, and the means available for disposing of forfeited assets. (
) The authority to seize property subject to forfeiture under any provision of
is granted to the Secretary of the Treasury in
USC §
The Secre- and tary’s authority is then delegated to the Commissioner of Internal Revenue Service in Treasury Order

, Seizure and Forfei- ture of Personal Property, further delegates seizure authority to special (
) The two primary statutes under the Internal Revenue Code (IRC) by which property can be forfeited are IRC §
and §
) Title
USC §

provides for the forfeiture of taxable property which is in the custody of any person intending it to be sold, removed, concealed, or in deposited to defraud the United States of the tax, or is possessed with the intent to avoid payment of the tax. It also provides for the forfeiture of assets used to manufacture, contain, or transport the taxable property that is the object of the fraud or evasion scheme. (
) As an example,
USC §
has been used to seize property for of the motor fuels excise tax laws. Motor fuels are considered a taxable property under
USC §
(a). Accordingly, it follows that any equipment that is used (such as computers used to track sales) under
USC any storage facilities for fuel under
USC §
(d), and any trucks that used to transport fuel under
USC §
(e), are all forfeitable if the fuel excise tax has been, or is intended to be, evaded. (
) Title
USC §

provides for the forfeiture of any property used, or intended for use, in violation of the provisions of the Internal Revenue laws in regulations prescribed under such laws. It is the more commonly used for a Title
forfeiture. The wording of
USC §
is very broad.
USC §

authorizes the seizure and forfeiture of any property used, or intended to be used to violate any of the Internal Revenue laws, it is not to used as a substitute to the collection of taxes. Consequently, most Title
feitures have involved property used to violate the provisions of the wagering tax laws (
USC §

Title 26 USC §7302 provides for the forfeiture of any property used, or intended for use, in violation of the provisions of the Internal Revenue laws or regulations prescribed under such laws. It is the more commonly used statute for a Title 26 forfeiture. The wording of 26 USC §7302 is very broad. Although 26 USC §7302 authorizes the seizure and forfeiture of any property used, or intended to be used to violate any of the Internal Revenue laws, it is not to be used as a substitute to the collection of taxes. Consequently, most Title 26 feitures have involved property used to violate the provisions of the wagering tax laws (26 USC §4401, §4411, and §4412), the sale of motor fuels (26 USC §4081 and §4091), and, to a lesser degree, the equipment used in these tax fraud schemes. Forfeiture can also apply to other sections, such as the sale

) The same assets listed in subsection
) above, can also be forfeited under
USC §
as property intended to be used to facilitate a violation of the Internal Revenue laws or its regulations. In addition, other applications of
USC §

have occasionally occurred. For example: a. A luxury car was forfeited because it was the investment object of a fraudulent tax shelter. b. In false refund investigations, computers and other equipment have been forfeited because they were used in the false refund operation. c. In wagering investigations, the currency or “bank” that was maintained by the operator of the business, was forfeited since the currency was needed in order to provide a sufficient supply of ready cash to meet the demands of the wagering business, that is, to pay off its winners. (
) Theoretically,
USC §
can be used to forfeit assets attributable to viola- tions of IRC
I (Form
, Report of Cash Payment over $
Received in a Trade or Business, filing requirements). However, as explained in subsection
below, the absence of a tracing provision in
USC §
makes these forfeitures very difficult to support. Unless the seizure occurs immediately after the transaction requiring the filing of a Form
, the money involved in the transaction would typically have already been deposited into the bank or else used in a subsequent transaction that would necessitate tracing. (
) In order to determine what type of property is subject to seizure, you must first look at the type of property that can be forfeited under Title
The language of
USC §
and §
does not specifically limit what type of property can be forfeited; however, the Title
forfeiture regulation,
CFR Part
, only addresses forfeiture of personal property. In addition, Delegation Order
only authorizes special agents to seize personal property. Since
USC §
and §

do not have a tracing provision, only the actual property used or intended to be used in violation of Internal Revenue laws is forfeitable. If the property is sold, traded, or exchanged for other property, then that other property is not forfeitable under Title
In addition, other property not subject to Title
forfeiture includes: a. assets that are the proceeds of the Title

violation (i.e., fraudulent refund checks) b. non-gaming amusement machines because there is no annual special oc- cupational tax imposed on such machines c. evidentiary records, such as books, ledgers, papers, and similar property d. leased property, since the lessor will generally be an innocent owner (
) Property seized under Title
can be either non-divisible or divisible. An example of non-divisible property would be an automobile. Once an automobile has been used to facilitate a violation of Title
, the entire automobile is for- feitable. The owner cannot argue that the automobile was only used
percent of the time, thereby requesting that

percent of the value be returned. Divisible property, on the other hand, is property that can be divided into smaller parts yet still retain the characteristics of the larger asset. Examples would be currency, gasoline, and diesel fuel. In order to seize divisible property, the government is only required to present a prima facie case as to the forfeitability of a portion of the property. for Forfeiture

page violate the Internal Revenue laws. If the owner is able to show this, then that portion of the property must be returned. This possibility should be in the pre-seizure planning stage of the seizure. (
) In transactions that violate IRC §
I, the purchased item is not forfeitable because it is not an instrument of the crime. Note: Forfeiture might be possible under
USC §
or §
if the property in the transaction represented proceeds from a specified unlawful activity. The money involved in the transaction that required the filing of the Form
, Report of Cash Payment over $

Received in a Trade or Business, would also be difficult to forfeit. Typically, this money is into the bank or used in a subsequent transaction. Absent a tracing provision, this money cannot be seized. (
) A business could be forfeitable if it could be shown that the primary reason the existence of the business is to facilitate IRC §
I violations. This would be very rare and would require advance pre-seizure planning with Area Counsel (Criminal Tax) assigned to your field office. (
) The burden of proof to seize property under Title

is probable cause. Although probable cause is technically all that is needed to forfeit property, several court cases have ruled that a preponderance of evidence is required before the asset can be forfeited. (
) Pre-seizure planning for a Title
seizure is, in many respects, similar to the pre-seizure planning that is conducted for a Title
seizure. Since IRM Pre-Seizure Planning, specifically addresses procedures relative to Title
seizures, a review of its material would be beneficial. However, there are ences in a Title
seizure that require different procedures to be followed. (

) As is the case with any seizure action, the first determination to make is whether the United States is likely to prevail in the ensuing forfeiture action. One step that will help achieve this goal is properly planning the seizure and anticipating any potential weaknesses and pitfalls that could prevent a suc- cessful forfeiture. Early consultation with Area Counsel and the United States Attorney’s Office (USAO), subject to appropriate disclosure limitations contained in subsection
below, will assist in laying the proper groundwork for our actions. With Title
forfeitures, the seized property con- tractor utilized in our Title
seizures cannot be used. Therefore, the steps taken to secure, store, maintain, and dispose of seized and forfeited property differ from the Title
seizures that result from our investigations. In as with other areas of Title
seizures, guidance and instructions come from existing Federal regulations, and not from other sources, such as the Executive Office for Asset Forfeiture. (
) Property that is seized and eventually forfeited in a Title

forfeiture belongs solely to the Internal Revenue Service. Proceeds must be deposited into the General Fund and are not subject to sharing with other law enforcement agencies. Arrangements for obtaining services and paying expenses will be to the individual field office and should be addressed in the pre-seizure stage of the action. For example, most expenses (i.e., towing, locksmiths, etc.) can be paid with a government issued credit card. Also, in some cases, other ar- rangements can be made. For example, Agency Wide Shared Services Internal Revenue Manual

violate the Internal Revenue laws. If the owner is able to show this, then that portion of the property must be returned. This possibility should be considered in the pre-seizure planning stage of the seizure.

(AWSS) will likely be able to help locate existing government space for storage. Expenses incurred relative to a Title 26 forfeiture are not subject to reimbursement by the Treasury Forfeiture Fund.

pated, a memorandum of support will be obtained from the appropriate This advice will be sought within the confines of IRC §

) The SAC will forward the above documents, together with a copy of the seizure warrant and affidavit (if a seizure has already been made) to his/her Director, Field Operations for concurrence. The Director, Field Operations forward the request to the Associate Director, Warrants and Forfeiture. The Associate Director, Warrants and Forfeiture will seek the advice and recom- mendation of Division Counsel regarding the request. (

) The Associate Director, Warrants and Forfeiture will prepare a memorandum the Chief, CI through the Director, Operations Policy and Support. If the Chief, CI, will refer the matter to the requesting SAC. If a judicial case, field office will prepare a transmittal memorandum and forward the package DOJ, Tax Division to pursue a judicial forfeiture. (
) Upon approval by the Chief, CI, the administrative forfeiture action may commence. (

) The Relation Back Doctrine maintains that the government’s interest in a ticular piece of property is established at the time it is used illegally, unless statute states otherwise. Technically, at that instant, all rights and legal title the asset pass to the government. Seizure and forfeiture proceedings, which must be undertaken, simply formalize the transfer of ownership that has already taken place. Accordingly, any liens placed on the property after the date the asset is used illegally are technically liens filed against government property. While third parties generally cannot acquire a legally recognizable interest in the asset after its illegal use, the Supreme Court has ruled that a good faith purchaser for value can assert an innocent owner defense prior to the government obtaining a judgment of forfeiture. In all instances, Area Counsel shall be consulted prior to releasing a tax lien or to releasing the seized property to satisfy a tax lien. (
) Since Title

seizures include motor fuel excise tax violations, it is possible that potentially contaminated property, such as a motor fuel tank, farm, gasoline stations, fuel trucks, etc., could be seized. Pre-seizure planning is perative because of the potential liability and poor marketability of this type property. It is the policy of the Department of Treasury and DOJ that contaminated, or potentially contaminated, can only be seized and forfeited with the approval of the USAO in the judicial district where the property is located. The decision whether to seize should be made in consultation with Area Counsel and AWSS. Further information relative to this topic is in subsection
below. (
) Procedures relative to the seizure of perishable goods are explained in
USC §

These concessions should be considered as part pre-seizure planning. Area Counsel and AWSS should also be consulted to seizure. Further information is contained in subsection
below.

) Since Title

seizures include motor fuel excise tax violations, it is possible that potentially contaminated property, such as a motor fuel tank, farm, barges, gasoline stations, fuel trucks, etc., could be seized. Pre-seizure planning is im- perative because of the potential liability and poor marketability of this type of property. It is the policy of the Department of Treasury and DOJ that property contaminated, or potentially contaminated, can only be seized and forfeited with the approval of the USAO in the judicial district where the property is located. The decision whether to seize should be made in consultation with Area Counsel and AWSS. Further information relative to this topic is contained in subsection
below. (
) Procedures relative to the seizure of perishable goods are explained in
USC §

If perishable goods are seized, special concessions are made to the owner of the property who can have the property returned in lieu of having it sold by the government. These concessions should be considered as part of pre-seizure planning. Area Counsel and AWSS should also be consulted prior
for Forfeiture
) The methods to effect seizures for Title
forfeiture are: a. warrant of arrest in rem b. seizure warrant c. seizure incident to a lawful arrest or search d. adoptive seizures (

) In very unusual circumstances, property taken from its lawful owner by individual and then turned over to IRS, can possibly be seized. However, the matter should first be reviewed by Area Counsel and will likely require the issuance of a seizure warrant or a warrant of arrest in rem. (
) A Warrant of Arrest in rem is used to seize property for Title

forfeitures when the proceedings are civil judicial. Proceedings in rem are governed by In Rem the Supplemental Rules for Admiralty and Maritime Claims. In addition to the USAO, Area Counsel must also be consulted so that they can review the affidavit for the warrant. They must also obtain concurrence from Division Counsel before a forfeiture action can be initiated. (
) A seizure warrant is another viable method for making a Title
seizure. Consult with Area Counsel since most Title

seizures will require the of Division Counsel. In a judicial matter involving return information in which Ex Parte Order has been obtained, Area Counsel can assist in preparing the affidavit for the warrant. This is to ensure compliance with the disclosure sions of
USC §
) Title
USC §
explicitly provides for forfeiture of property seized to search warrants issued as authorized in
USC Chapter
and the Federal Rules of Criminal Procedure. While
USC §
is silent on the of search or seizure warrants, they are the preferred methods. (

) If a determination is made that property seized incident to an arrest or a search is subject to forfeiture, the matter must be referred to Area Counsel their advice. A memorandum, stating the facts and circumstances and fully detailing the evidence that supports forfeiture should be included in the advisory request to Area Counsel. Equally applicable to Title

action the Treasury Executive Office of Asset Forfeiture recommends that property incident to an arrest or search warrant, be re-seized utilizing a seizure if it is subsequently determined the property is subject to forfeiture. (
) Although possible, adoptive seizures will be rare since there are no for sharing with state, local, or Federal agencies. In Title
forfeitures, adoption requests must be reviewed by Area Counsel and are subject to the same review and approval as with Title
adoptions. (
) The following subsections are the procedures to be followed when seized assets for Title
forfeiture. The procedures are similar to those for Title
forfeitures, except as noted below.
Asset Seizure and (
) The majority of case law that addresses Title

forfeiture of currency the seizure of currency from wagering operations. The courts have upheld forfeiture of currency when it could be shown the currency was involved in illegal gambling and that it was being used to further the illegal activity, and merely the proceeds of the activity. It must be shown that it was an “active in the violation. This same logic should be used for other Title
forfeiture situations. (
) Domestic and foreign currency seized for Title

forfeiture, except when as evidence or a collectible asset, is to be deposited into the IRS suspense account within five days of seizure. The currency should be converted into a cashier’s check or money order made payable to the “Internal Revenue Service” and forwarded to Internal Revenue Service, Beckley Finance
N. Heber St., Beckley WV
, Attention: Seized Asset Accountant. A copy of the AFTRAK Seizure Asset Transcript Report, used to record the seizure on AFTRAK should accompany the check. (

) The use of safe deposit boxes or other similar methods of storing seized currency is no longer acceptable, except when necessary for temporary storage or in storing currency to be held for evidentiary purposes. (
) If currency is seized solely for evidentiary purposes or as part of a Title
vestigation, written approval must be obtained in order to retain the currency IRS custody. If the amount is less than $
, a written request from the USAO, or a memorandum signed by the SAC, must be obtained and main- tained in the seizure file. If the amount equals or exceeds $

, written approval must be obtained from the Director, Operations Policy and Support and maintained in the seizure file. If only a portion of the seized currency evidentiary value, only that portion with the evidentiary value should be retained. (
) If seized currency being held as evidence is later deposited to the IRS suspense account, then its evidentiary value no longer exists and some needs to be taken within
days of the date of deposit. (
) Financial accounts include checking, savings, money market, mutual funds, and brokerage accounts. They can be either seized or frozen at the financial institution. (

) Unless the account is frozen, immediately upon seizure of the account, the financial institution should be directed to prepare a cashier’s check for the value of the account, made payable to the “Internal Revenue Service”. The check should be deposited into the IRS suspense account by following the cedures listed in subsection
) above. (
) Unlike Title
forfeitures in which financial instruments, promissory notes, currency are typically forfeited as proceeds of a specified unlawful activity,

forfeitures require that the asset be used, or intended to be used, to tate the crime (i.e., to be an active aid in furtherance of the crime). This requirement and the lack of a tracing provision have made it very difficult to forfeit financial instruments (i.e., postal money orders, personal or business checks, stocks and bonds, etc.) and cashier’s checks, using Title
Financial accounts include checking, savings, money market, mutual funds, and brokerage accounts. They can be either seized or frozen at the

) If business, personal, or bank checks are seized, the seizing agent should expeditiously to ensure the funds are preserved. In addition to notifying the drawee bank, the following procedures should be followed: a. When the check is made payable to cash or the payee is left blank, the instrument shall be photocopied and the check should be forwarded to Director, Field Operations with a request that it be endorsed in his/her capacity. The check will be presented to the drawee bank, if possible, or a cooperating financial institution and utilized to purchase a cashier’s check made payable to the “Internal Revenue Service”. The cashier’s check should then be deposited to the IRS suspense account by the procedures listed in subsection

) below. b. When the check is made payable to a designated payee, a letter should be sent from the Director, Field Operations to the drawee’s financial insti- tution advising that the check being presented was seized pursuant to
USC §

The letter should also request that the check be certified completion of the forfeiture proceedings. ) Once an asset has been identified, pre-seizure steps have been taken, and seizure occurs, an authorization for forfeiture must be obtained. The a Forfeiture although similar, differs in many ways from the forfeiture process utilized in Title
forfeitures. Because Title

) Within ten days following seizure, a referral should be forwarded to Area Counsel assigned to your area. It is the responsibility of the Asset Forfeiture Coordinator (AFC) to ensure that all necessary documents and information obtained from the case agent and included in the referral to Area Counsel. (

) After receiving the referral, Area Counsel will review the facts and circum- stances of the seizure and the documents provided. If the proposed forfeiture is administrative and pertains to either a violation of IRC §
I or the wagering tax provisions of
USC §
, and/or §
, then Area Counsel can recommend that a forfeiture action be initiated. If it pertains to any other Title
matter, then it has to be referred to Division Counsel, who will review the matter within three days. If they concur, then the matter is forwarded to DOJ, Tax Division. (
) Within
calendar days after receipt of the referral, Area Counsel will provide
opinion on the legal basis, or lack thereof, for forfeiture and provide the with a recommendation whether or not the property should be forfeited. (

) If Area Counsel’s Law and Fact Memorandum recommends against and the SAC disagrees, a conference will be arranged so that both parties discuss the matter. If Area Counsel’s position is unchanged, the SAC will be notified by memorandum. (

) The SAC may protest Area Counsel’s position by preparing a report setting forth the reasons for disagreement, and forwarding it for the concurrence of Director, Field Operations. This report will be forwarded to the Chief, CI, copy sent to Area Counsel. The Chief, CI, will negotiate the matter with Division Counsel and notify the SAC of the final decision. (
) If an administrative forfeiture is recommended by either Area Counsel or Division Counsel, the field office AFC will mail a Notice of Intent to Forfeit Letter (Exhibit
) to all potential claimants within ten days of receipt the recommendation. The letter must be mailed within
days of the date seizure. (

) The Notice of Intent to Forfeit Letter will be mailed by certified or registered mail to all known potential claimants. The letter will explain the claimant’s to file a Petition for Remission or Mitigation of Forfeiture, a Claim and a Bond, or an Offer in Compromise. The notice will also specify the IRS upon which the forfeiture is based, the newspaper in which the notice of seizure will be published, the dates of publication, the final claim date, and forfeiture date. (

) The Law and Fact Memorandum from Area Counsel that recommends istrative forfeiture of the property will instruct that a notice of seizure must placed in a newspaper of general circulation in the judicial district where the seizure occurred. The field office AFC is responsible for ensuring that the notice is published within
days of the date of seizure. (

) The notice must be published once a week for three consecutive weeks the first notice must be coordinated to be published at the same time as the mailing of the Notice of Intent to Forfeit Letter. The notice must describe the items seized, and state the time, place, and cause for the seizure. (
) The final claim date will be
days from the first date of publication of the notice of seizure. (
) Provided no petitions or claims are received, the forfeiture date is
days the first day of publication of the Notice of Seizure. (
) In an administrative forfeiture case, a completed Form
, Declaration of Forfeiture (Exhibit
), will be sent to the Director, Field Operations, authorized by Delegation Order
to execute the declaration and forfeit property administratively on behalf of the Internal Revenue Service. (
) The original Form
, Declaration of Forfeiture, signed by the Director, Operations will be maintained in the seizure file and a copy will be to Area Counsel. Internal Revenue Manual

, the property may be sold after forfeiture. Following the sale, the proceeds shall be used to pay all costs of the seizure and forfeiture. Any remaining balance shall be paid to the peti- tioner. If the petitioner is a creditor, then the petitioner would only receive the remaining balance up to the outstanding balance of the loan. The remainder will be deposited to the General Fund. (

) The Director, Operations Policy and Support can also enter into an with the petitioner to place the forfeited asset into official use. In those instances, the IRS will pay the petitioner the appraised value of the asset the amount of any costs. Similarly, if the petitioner is a creditor, the payment will be up to the remaining balance of the loan.

, the property may be sold after forfeiture. Following the sale, the proceeds shall be used to pay all costs of the seizure and forfeiture. Any remaining balance shall be paid to the peti- tioner. , any person claiming an interest in the property seized may file a claim and post a cost bond prior to Bond the final claim date. (
) Although there are no provisions in the Title

statutes or regulations for foregoing the filing of a cost bond, there is sufficient case law that allows a claimant to proceed In Forma Pauperis. Internal Revenue Service policy is afford any potential claimant the maximum opportunity to retrieve their property. Therefore, the Notice of Intent to Forfeit Letter sent to potential claimants shall reference this proceeding as an option. Form

) The sureties of a cost bond must meet these requirements: a. The bond amount shall be in the amount of $

b. The bond must be conditioned that in the case of condemnation of the property seized, the obligors shall pay all the costs and expenses of the proceedings to obtain such condemnation. c. The bond may be in cash, certified check, cashier’s check, postal order, or satisfactory surety bonds. Checks and money orders are to be made payable to the Internal Revenue Service. d. United States bonds, notes, or other obligations on which the interest principal are unconditionally guaranteed by the United States (US bonds which are not transferable are not acceptable, see Treasury Department Circular
and

) are also acceptable. e. A corporate surety bond may be filed only if the surety company issuing the bond holds a Certificate of Authority from the Secretary of Treasury being an acceptable surety. Corporate surety bonds are subject to the tations prescribed by Treasury Department Circular
, as amended. f. If a claim is received, it should be forwarded to Area Counsel, who will review the matter, and, if required, will forward it to Division Counsel. (

) above. The AFTRAK Seizure Asset Transcript Report, per- taining to the original seizure should accompany the deposit. ) An Offer in Compromise is an offer proposed by the owner of the property subject to forfeiture, who wishes to negotiate the forfeiture. It can only be Compromise proposed in an administrative forfeiture action. It cannot be considered case has been referred to DOJ or USAO. (

) Property disposed of either administratively or judicially under the Title

may be disposed of as follows: of Forfeited a. deposited into the General Fund (currency, negotiable instruments, proceeds of any financial account or proceeds from the sale of seized property) b. placed into official use c. returned to owner, claimant, or petitioner d. destroyed pursuant to court order, or in the case of coin-operated devices, by order of the Director, Field Operations e. transferred to GSA for disposition (

through

These regulations state that: a. A notice of sale must be placed in a newspaper of general circulation published in the judicial district wherein the seizure was made. b. The sale shall not occur sooner than ten days from the date of the cation of the notice. c. Each asset must be sold separately if competitive bids are solicited. d. All personal property is to be sold “ as is” and with no guarantee or warranty implied or expressed. e. The United States reserves the right to reject any bid. f. All prospective bidders must complete a Bidder Registration Form (at time of registration if auctioned, or with the submission of the bid if a gotiated sale or sealed bid). Completion of this form represents the Internal Revenue Manual Cat. No.

reasury as being an acceptable surety, and which has processagents in the judicial district where the person resides or the obligationis to be performed, and where the bond is retumnable or filed.
The claim of ownership and cost bond should be sent to the following:
ADMINISTRATIVE REVIEW

Administrative review is obtained by filing with this office, a written petition forremission or mitigation of forfeiture of the property under 26 USC §7327 and 19USC §1618. This request may be filed at any time before the final disposition ofthe property. You may also file with this office, by (Insert Final Claim Date), thefinal claim date, and Offer in Compromise under 26 USC §7122 fo settle theforfeiture liability incurred by the property. The petition must include the seizurenumber, description of the property seized, the date of seizure, proof of yourownership interest in the property, the facts and circumstances that you believejustify the return of the property, and must be signed and sworn to under oath byyou. You are advised that any petition or Offer in Compromise filed is subject toinvestigation.
Exhibit 9.7.13-1 (Cont. 2) (08-11-2003) Notice of Intent to Forfeit Letter

Should the Chief, Criminal Investigation, find that the forfeiture was incurredwithout willful negligence or without any intention on the part of the petitioner todefraud the revenue or to violate the law, or finds the existence of such mitigatingcircumstances as to justify the remission or mitigation of such forfeiture, theChief, Criminal Investigation, may remit or mitigate the same upon such termsand conditions as he/she deems reasonable and just.
WARNING CONCERNING FORFEITURE PROCEDURE

The administrative forfeiture is not normally subject to judicial review. If a claimof ownership and cost bond are timely filed, any pending petition for remission ormitigation of forfeiture of the property or an Offer in Compromise to settleforfeiture liability will be transferred to the Department of Justice for theappropriate action. You are cautioned that the timely filing of a petition forremission or mitigation of forfeiture does not extend the time for filing a validclaim of ownership and a cost bond.
Should you have any questions concerning this matter, please contact (InsertName of AFC), Asset Forfeiture Coordinator at (Insert Phone Number).
